title: What Active Listening Really Means
content: Active listening goes beyond hearing. It requires full attention, suspension of judgment, and genuine effort to understand the speaker's meaning—not just their words. In operations, poor listening causes more errors than poor speaking. You can't respond correctly to information you didn't fully receive.

mcq.question: During a handover, you're thinking about your response while your colleague is still speaking. What's the problem?

options.B: You're not fully listening and may miss critical information
options.C: It's fine if you catch the main points

mcq.explanation: Formulating responses while someone speaks divides attention. Active listening requires full focus on the speaker. The few seconds saved aren't worth missing critical information.
